item.title: U.S. universities have lost sight of their core task
item.description: It’s time for higher education to get back to educating the workforce of the future.

item.title: The autism epidemic is a myth
item.description: Most new cases reflect mild or no significant impairment. Moderate and severe cases have declined.

item.title: A drug for myopia could help millions of kids. The FDA is keeping it off the shelves.
item.description: American children with myopia deserve better than this regulatory failure.

item.title: 26 is the new 22. Why not for this Social Security program?
item.description: The age cutoff reflects an outdated assumption about how adulthood unfolds.

item.title: Trump is making voters uneasy. Democrats are pushing them away.
item.description: Punishing the wealthy might make Democrats feel good, but it won’t convince many voters.

item.title: We may be doing breast cancer screening all wrong
item.description: This test may be crucial for breast cancer screening. It’s not a mammogram.

item.title: It’s Taxachusetts for a reason
item.description: The Bay State is losing businesses and residents to lower-tax competitors.

item.title: California to Seahawks: Pay up
item.description: Winning the Super Bowl in California means more taxes than winning it somewhere else.

item.title: The lion’s share
item.description: Michael Ramirez cartoon on the impact of the Epstein files in U.S. versus U.K.

item.title: Snow should not be an emergency. Keep DMV kids in school.
item.description: Readers on issues such as snow removal, the debt crisis, D.C. Health and the Potomac sewage spill

item.title: Is Europe ready to send troops to Ukraine? I answered your questions.
item.description: David’s live chat with readers started at 12 p.m. ET on Monday. Read the transcript.

item.title: A de facto death sentence for publishing a newspaper
item.description: Jimmy Lai’s fate mirrors Hong Kong’s.

item.title: Universities are sending Trump a dangerous message
item.description: Higher education is under attack. Drop the appeasement.

item.title: The best evidence against Trump’s tariffs? His own first term.
item.description: Without tariffs, the first year of the president’s first term saw a healthier economy than 2025.

item.title: Trump’s alleged fear of the ICC reflects the company he’s in
item.description: The president’s indifference to domestic legal constraints is reflected in his actions outside the U.S.

item.title: How the Russian people are returning to Europe
item.description: The Council of Europe bets that Russia is more than its regime — and prepares for inevitable change.

item.title: The world economy is thriving. It reveals a disconnect.
item.description: Despite the grim sentiment, global trends are positive. That mismatch has consequences.

item.title: The hidden costs of Costa Rica’s ecotourism boom
item.description: Planetary gentrification comes to paradise

item.title: Big win for Japan’s prime minister is good news for the U.S.
item.description: Sanae Takaichi shows that standing up to China pays politically.

item.title: The only way to ensure diversity of thought on college campuses
item.description: Readers on academic freedom and tax season woes.

item.title: The cost of Trump’s madman theory on tariffs
item.description: The president’s erratic nature can be a strength, but it’s also his biggest liability.

item.title: China’s ill-fated gambit to dethrone the dollar
item.description: The only way the U.S. dollar loses its primacy is self-sabotage.
